III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Medical and dental care policy.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12413
Section • (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
Description include all the following:
1

• (d) Current immunizations for each child as required
by section 5111 of the public health code, 1978 PA
368, MCL 333.5111. All the following apply:
• (ii) A copy of a waiver addressed to the
department that is signed by the parent
stating immunizations are not being
administered due to religious, medical, or
other reasons is sufficient documentation of
immunizations, unless the child is a
temporary court ward, a motion is heard, and
order is entered by the circuit court for the
child's case. A waiver must be accompanied
by a certification by the local health
department that the parent or parents
received education on the risks of not
receiving the vaccines being waived and the
benefits of vaccination to the individual and
the community as required by section 5111 of
the public health code, 1978 PA 368, MCL
333.5111, and R 325.176(12).
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth received immunizations without parental consent.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on February 27,
2025. They reported no additional information.
Foster Care Supervisor (FC Supervisor) was interviewed via
video conference on February 19, 2025. Youth A has been in
Methodist’s program since June 2024. FC Supervisor stated
Youth A received immunization during his initial medical
appointment in July 2024. Methodist didn’t have the case when
Youth A initially came into care. DHS had the case until Youth A
entered Independent Living (IL) in June 2024 and they were not
informed of any issues with parents refusing immunizations and
Youth A didn’t indicate anything either.
During the video call, FC Supervisor continued to look to her left.
During the interview a voice was heard when discussing
immunizations. Chief Administrator (CA) spoke up and stated
she was sitting on the other side of the room. She stated this is
Youth A’s second time in care and he received immunizations
during his first time in care. They ran medical passports when he
first came to their agency and saw that he received
immunizations, so they weren’t aware of any parental refusal. She
2

stated Foster Care Worker (FCW) accompanied Youth A to the
appointment where he received immunizations at his initial
medical in July 2024 and he didn’t vocalize any concern with
receiving them. He stated he didn’t want the COVID vaccine so
that wasn’t administered but that was the only one he objected to.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via telephone on
February 21, 2025. He stated Youth A is in the agency’s
Independent Living Plus program. FCW stated when Youth A
entered the IL program, he arranged the initial medical in July
2024. Part of the initial medical appointment for Youth A included
some immunizations. He stated Youth A had previously received
immunizations but was behind so FCW assumed it was
acceptable to administer in order for Youth A to be caught up on
immunizations. Youth A did not verbalize any objection to the
immunizations other than the COVID 19 vaccination, so he was
not given that one. Youth A had been removed previously and
administered immunizations, so he wasn’t aware biological
parents objected. He stated after the initial medical appointment,
FCW spoke with Biological Mother and she advised she did not
want Youth A to receive any immunizations. FCW stated he
explained to Biological Mother he wasn’t aware she objected to
immunizations and that he had received some at the initial
medical appointment. FCW stated he is working on obtaining a
waiver but that has not been completed yet.
Biological Mother was interviewed via telephone on February
27, 2025. Biological Mother stated there was never any discussion
between her and the agency regarding her stance on
immunizations. She stated one of her other children mentioned
receiving “shots” so she asked all of her children and was told
they had also received immunizations. She spoke with FCW and
explained she didn’t want Youth A or her other children to receive
immunizations. She stated FCW seemed to be confused that he
wasn’t supposed to do that without parental consent.
Youth A was interviewed via telephone on March 12, 2025. He
stated he recalled getting shots in the past but couldn’t recall what
they were. He appeared to be somewhat confused by the
questions but stated he reported he did not want to get the COVID
19 vaccine. He stated he was told later after the appointment by
FCW that Biological Mother did not want him to get
immunizations.
Documents reviewed:
3

• MISACWIS case file for Youth A. Lists approximately 24
immunizations dating back to 2008 up until 2024. There is not
a waiver uploaded in the case file.
• Agency immunization policy states:
Nonmedical Waiver: Parents or guardians who object to
immunizations for religious or philosophical reasons must
contact the local county health department to schedule an
appointment for the nonmedical waiver education sessions
and obtain the required certified waiver. For children not
enrolling in the programs or grades listed above, the
nonmedical waiver from the previous year is acceptable.
Parent Objection: For children who do not fall into the
categories noted in Michigan Administrative Code R
325.176, but whose parent(s) or legal guardian(s) opposes
immunizations for religious or philosophical reasons, a
written, signed, and dated statement documenting the
parent’s objection to each specific immunization being
refused is required. The parental objection statement must
be updated annually.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of Youth A’s MISACWIS case file Biological
Mother did not inform the agency of her objection to
immunizations and a waiver was not on file prior to Youth A
receiving immunizations.
Consultation
Consultation was provided for agency to consider updating policy
and procedures to ask parents if they oppose to their child(ren)
receiving immunizations when they begin working with the family
and document within the case file.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Visitation and family time; in person contact.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421
Section • (3) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between
Description parents and children except where parental rights have
been terminated or when there is a court determination that
visits are detrimental to the child.
4

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency has denied parental visitation.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone. They reported no
additional information.
Foster Care Supervisor (FC supervisor) was interviewed via
video conference on February 19, 2025. FC Supervisor reported
parenting time has been consistently offered to Biological Mother
on a weekly basis. There have been occasions when Youth A
leaves school or leaves the agency property and does not return
in time to be transported to parenting time. The majority of the
time that has occurred he returns with Biological Mother
unsupervised and against the court order. FC Supervisor is aware
of one scheduled visit where transportation fell through but FCW
rescheduled for later in the week. Visits usually take place at
Catholic Charities who has full family responsibility and case
management of 2 of Youth A’s younger siblings. She isn’t aware
of a situation where parenting time was missed or missed and not
able to be made up. The other agency with case management
responsibility for the other children provided mother with Uber
rides due to her having two broken legs and Methodist transported
the IL youth to the visit location.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via telephone on
February 21, 2025. FCW stated Youth A has weekly supervised
time with Biological Mother. He stated Youth A has never missed
a parenting time other than a month or so when he first entered IL
due to parents refusing visits. A parenting time exception was
entered in the case file from June 12, 2024-September 9, 2024.
He stated Youth A has been sneaking out of the IL home and
going to Biological Mother’s house and having dinner. Both Youth
A and Biological Mother are aware this is a violation of the court
order that states parenting time must be supervised but continue
to do it anyway. He asked Youth A and Biological Mother to sign a
safety plan regarding unsupervised contact but they both refused.
The other agency with case management responsibility for the
other children provided mother with Uber rides due to her having
two broken legs. Mother did not visit while he was in inpatient
psychiatric hospital.
Biological Mother was interviewed via telephone on February
27, 2025. Biological Mother stated she missed several visits with
Youth A in the early summer into fall 2024. She stated FCW had
advised he couldn’t transport Youth A to parenting time. She was
5

never offered any make up visits. The court order stated the
agency was supposed to assist her with transportation for visits.
Youth A was interviewed via telephone on March 12, 2025. He
reported he has supervised visits with Biological Mother. He
reported supervised visits taking place every week but sometimes
they were every 2 weeks. He recalled there were a few visits that
did not take place due Biological Mother’s lack of transportation.
He could not recall when that happened.
Documents reviewed:
• MISACWIS case file for Youth A. Visitation plan states
parenting time is 1 hour per week supervised.
• August 6, 2024, court order states DHHS shall assist parents
with transportation to visits.
• Social work contacts reviewed indicate parenting time
occurred with Biological Mother and Youth A on a weekly
basis except between June 19, 2024-August 8, 2024.
Parenting time exception in the MISACWIS case file from
June 12, 2024-September 9, 2024, due to parents refusing
visits. In addition, March 27, 2025, service plan indicated
parenting time did not take place on January 19, 2025, due
to Youth A being hospitalized from January 14, 2025-
January 22, 2025.
• Social work contact on January 8, 2025, states parenting
time held with Biological Mother and Youth A’s siblings,
however Youth A did not come home from school that day
and was not present for the parenting time.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of Youth A’s MISACWIS case file the
agency has complied with the court order of 1 hour supervised
parenting time per week with Biological Mother. There was a 6-
week block when parenting time did not occur however there is a
parenting time exception entered for this timeframe due to parents
refusing visits. In addition, there were 2 occasions when parenting
time with Youth A did not occur, however the agency documented
valid reasons for the missed parenting time.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Policy and procedures
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12503
Section • (2) The policies and procedures must cover at least all the
Description following areas:
6

• (i) Medical, dental, and mental health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Parental consent was not obtained for psychotropic medication.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone. They reported no
additional information.
Foster Care Supervisor (FC supervisor) was interviewed via
video conference on February 19, 2025. FC Supervisor stated
any medication Youth A is taking was agreed upon by Biological
Mother. There was at least one medication Biological Mother was
not in agreement with Youth A taking but she could not recall
which medication. Biological Mother didn’t sign the 1643 so that
particular medication was not given to Youth A due to Biological
Mother not being in agreement. She isn’t aware of anything
regarding Amphetamine Salts. The 1643 includes the medication
dose range and Biological Mother signed the form indicating she
was in agreement.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via telephone on
February 21, 2025. FCW reported Biological Mother would not
agree for Youth A to receive antidepressant medication for a long
time. She eventually agreed and signed the consent form only
after he attempted to commit suicide and was hospitalized.
Biological Mother was interviewed via telephone on February
27, 2025. She stated Youth A is on Adderall or the generic form.
Youth A started it approximately 1 month ago. She stated she was
in agreement with the medication, but she disagreed with the
starting dose. She felt based on his height and weight it was too
high. When Youth A initially started taking the medication he
began picking at his chest. She stated she reported to the
prescriber she felt the 15mg starting dose was too high and the
prescriber disagreed. Biological Mother stated Youth A is now 15
pounds lighter than he was and she feels that is due to the
medication side effects. She stated she recalls signing a consent
form for Youth A to take the medication but felt pressured by the
physician to do so. She was not able to provide detail regarding
how she felt pressured. She clarified she agrees with the
medication but not the dose.
Youth A was interviewed via telephone on March 12, 2025. He
stated there was a recent dose change for his Adderall. He has
noticed an improvement since the dose change and does not
7

have any concerns. He is not aware if Biological Mother provided
consent for the medication but thought she had.
Documents reviewed:
• MISACWIS case file for Youth A:
• DHS 1643 Psychotropic Medication Informed Consent form
dated December 11, 2024. Signed by Youth A, Biological
Mother and physician. Medication is Focalin XR; starting
dose is 10mg and maximum dose is 30mg.
• DHS 1643 Psychotropic Medication Informed Consent form
dated January 28, 2025. Signed by Youth A, Biological
Mother and physician. Medication is Mirtazapine; starting
dose is 30mg and maximum dose is 45mg. Adderall XR;
starting dose is 15mg and maximum dose is 30mg.
Discontinued Focalin XR and Trileptal (Oxcarbazepine).
• Agency policies and procedures do not specifically address
psychotropic medication. It addresses how they determine
if a youth can self-administer and self-manage their own
medications.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of Youth A’s MISACWIS case file, the
agency obtained consent from Biological Mother prior to providing
a psychotropic medication to Youth A. The consent form included
the dose range of the medication.
Technical Assistance
Technical assistance was offered the agency update agency
policy to include requirements for psychotropic medication
consent.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Medical, dental and mental health care.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12507
Section • (1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent
Description living receives any needed medical, dental, and mental
health care as required in R 400.12413. Medical, dental,
and mental health care provided must be documented in
the youth's record.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency is not ensuring youth has access to all needed medical
and mental health care.
8

Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone. They reported no
additional information.
Foster Care Supervisor (FC Supervisor) was interviewed via
video conference on February 19, 2025. FC Supervisor reported
Youth A has been in Methodist’s program since June 2024. FC
Supervisor stated she is not aware of Youth A having any medical
issues. He has had some mental health struggles and was
hospitalized in an inpatient program recently for approximately
one week. There was an incident that precipitated the inpatient
hospitalization. FC Supervisor clarified that Youth A’s biological
father is engaging in a sexual relationship with Youth A’s girlfriend
and he recently found out it was occurring. FC Supervisor
reported the agency provides transportation for Youth A to attend
any necessary appointments. Youth A is currently seeing a
psychiatrist and attends counseling.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via telephone on
February 21, 2025. He stated Youth A is in the agency’s ILP
program. The only instance when Youth A verbalized being
depressed was when he found out his father was involved in a
sexual relationship with his girlfriend. At that time, Youth A
attempted suicide and was hospitalized for inpatient mental health
treatment for almost one week. Youth A attends counseling
weekly and participates in monthly medication reviews. FCW
stated Youth A does not want to be in the ILP program because
he wants to be home with Biological Mother. Other than that, the
agency is not aware of any unaddressed medical or mental health
needs.
Biological Mother was interviewed via telephone on February
27, 2025. Biological Mother was asked about concerns regarding
Youth A’s medical and mental health. She stated Youth A has
exhibited behaviors such as going awol, cutting, depression and
suicide attempts since being removed from her care. She stated
Youth A sees a psychiatrist once a month or every 2 weeks and
also sees a counselor. She doesn’t recall every being given Youth
A’s medical passport and stated the agency doesn’t communicate
well regarding medical and mental health services Youth A is
receiving or participating in.
Youth A was interviewed via telephone on March 12, 2025. He
stated there are no medical or mental health services that are not
being addressed. He feels the agency has responded
appropriately when he has told them about any of his needs.
Documents reviewed:
9

• MISACWIS case file for Youth A. Service plans document
Youth A attends counseling approximately twice per month
and sees a psychiatrist once per month for depression and
PTSD.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of Youth A’s MISACWIS case file it appears
Youth A’s medical and mental health needs are being met.
Consultation:
Consultation was offered for the agency to inform parents of
medical, dental and mental health appointments.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be continued.
